Author: cmccann77
Content:
$5000 isn't worth the risk of using 500 non-accredited investors. If you really believe in your company my advice is to put some real sweat equity into your business and 
a. get a part time job, restaurant servers get good tips
b. take out a credit card
c. liquidate everything you can to afford it
d. or a combination of all three

Author: boucher
Content:
Good introductory text: Cormen/Leiserson/Rivest/Stein: Introduction to Algorithms (2nd edition)

http://www.amazon.com/Introduction-Algorithms-Thomas-H-Corme...

Good advanced text: Jon Kleinberg/Eva Tardos: Algorithm Design

http://www.amazon.com/Algorithm-Design-Jon-Kleinberg/dp/0321...

Author: yearsinrock
Content: I think this reply perfectly answers my question.

Author: boucher
Content:
Well, no, not always, always.

Use the data structure that makes the design more efficient. Clarity might be nice, but an O(n) solution is not acceptable when a reasonable O(log n) or O(1) solution exists.

Author: paul
Content: The shoreline area of Mountain View (where Google is located) is largely old landfill. There are still some flaming methane vents around (or there were a few years ago).

Author: henryw
Content: LOL "Java is like a variant of the game of Tetris in which none of the pieces can fill gaps created by the other pieces, so all you can do is pile them up endlessly."

Author: bls
Content: A recommendation for/against a particular designer is worthless without some kind of description of your first-hand experience with the designer. You wouldn't do business with them again? Why not? You loved working with them and the result made you tons of money? Please say so, and provide a link to the result.
